title: When will the Federal Reserve announce it will conclude its monthly quantitative easing bond buying?
preds: A bit late to the party here but I'm trying to rattle through all the questions in the inflation challenge and I've not answered this one.

“Fed officials announced after their early November meeting that they would begin to slow the bond purchases at a pace of $15 billion a month, effectively ending the program in the middle of 2022. Once that program is complete, the door is open for the Fed to begin lifting its fed funds target rate to zero.” https://www.google.com/search?q=when+will+fed+end+quantitative+easing&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&hl=en-us&client=safari
if they stick to their announced time table, they will conclude in the middle of 2022
Updating based on Fed announcement today that they are accelerating the taper.

The FED has not yet started to tighten. Buying fewer treasuries doesn't mean they are tightening, it means they are expanding the money supply by less than they used to be. They are still pouring gas on the fire. They won't be tightening until they stop purchases altogether and raise the federal funds rate to above about 6%, which will never happen.  My point in saying this is that as soon as the stock market starts to stutter they will reverse course. This isn't really about fighting inflation. It's just about trying to keep public confidence up. They want to look like they are doing something.
Hard to imagine it ending any time past May at this point. Furman thinks March: https://twitter.com/jasonfurman/status/1471154572877983744?t=kJ6l7wvXgjqEpo5zu7Sa_A&s=19

The FED still operates slowly but public comments have pointed towards an earlier tapering. It’s going to take a few months of wait and see from the FED to determine directionally where the economy is going.
They basically told us in November they would do 15/month and end in June. Now they are all telling us it will be sped up. I leave a 5% tail in case of exogenous shock.
Updating based on Powell quotes in the news.
Pressure to make the change is increasing
Concerns for inflation will put pressure to ease buying.  But still in controlled manor to not startle markets.

Any change in language will prompt a further aligning of probabilities in sync with a more aggressive schedule : "At their Dec. 14-15 meeting, Fed officials also could consider revamping their policy statement to stop characterizing higher inflation as “transitory” and to clarify their outlook for interest-rate increases next year." (-WSJ)

I believe they would like to conclude their bond buying and begin raising rates mid-2022, but I just have trouble believing that they CAN. US fiscal debt has ballooned, excess liquidity has poured into risky assets (meaning a disaster if it begins to unravel or liquidity tightens too quickly), and with China moving away from USD/UST, someone needs to keep the gov't solvent and assets from crashing.

If the Fed was going to fight inflation they would have done it a long time ago. With interest rates at zero and with quantitative easing still continuing, they are still pouring gasoline on the fire of inflation they are just pouring a little less. As soon as the stock market starts falling or bond rates start rising trend they will reverse course and increase quantitative easing again.

It is almost certain that the Federal Reserve will have to roll back its policy of quantitative easing as there are more indicators that the current inflation is not a temporary effect of the pandemic on global supply chains. That said, the question was when to fully conclude not reduce. Given the struggling labor market in the US and fear of another covid wave caused by a new variant, I think that the Fed will likely hesistate to make any major shifts in the short term until the impacts of the Omicron variant are better understood which will likely take a few months.
Comments recently by Powell that inflation may not be as "transitory" as previously expected.
Fed Chairman Powell recently announced that Fed will speed up thier timetable and dropped the use of transitory inflation

1) The key is the difference between the announcement and the end 2) The question is about the announcement 3) Fed already said they planned to reduce purchases at a rate that would effectively end the program in Summer 2022 3) They like to give lots of time for adjustment so there isn't a shock (good luck) so the announcement would have to come in 1qrtr.

They have inflated every single asset, their fastest tool is boring cadence, now  can they affor to deflate what they own or to wait?
Wait or stop purchases will kill the golden goose. If the Fed stops buying and bond prices continue to decline, that is a pickle, it puts the Fed assets in the red. It is going to be and interesting debate, who pick up those bonds or the Fed should carry forward a loss for the next 15 to 20 years, or the banks will need another bail out!
updating given powell congressional testimony discussing potential for accelerated taper - not a done deal but dramaticly shifts odds if fed chair believes conversation on it is appropriate
Pure guesswork.  The Fed will be under real pressure to continue, but pressure to stop will increase.  Action will have little to do with quantitative economics.

From my perspective, monetary policy has already been far too "loose", and a tightening is already past due. However, I do not sit on the Fed Board of Governors! They obviously have their own ideas, which thus far have meant a reluctance to begin tightening in earnest. I do not see a sudden change of heart, and a high likelihood that they will drag their feet - quite possibly for too long. I also think it likely that they will refrain from making any changes to monetary policy between July and Election Day, out of fear of influencing the election, or of being suspected of doing so. My assignment of probabilities is thus bimodal.

An announcement that they will completely end QE would likely be done only if the economic and labor situations were on really stable ground, otherwise, markets are likely to digest the news as a rate hike by another means, which in turn could have adverse consequences. While the Fed would like to wind up QE by next summer, I think they will find excuses to keep it going for a lot longer, especially given the uncertainty prevailing in today’s world (COVID variants, etc.)

Powell just said today that they're going to conclude the taper sooner 'perhaps a few months earlier'.
https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/markets/dow-falls-by-600-points-after-fed-chair-powell-says-he-d-like-to-speed-up-tapering/ar-AARjbo4?ocid=uxbndlbing

Much has been made over the fact that the FED has not committed to a taper. So far all it has done is lowered the minimum amount of asset purchases per month. Technically speaking the FED has not committed to reducing its purchases.  I bring this up because when the FED makes a statement about something that it is going to do this is an action as much as the actual action itself is. Right now it seems the market is reassured by the idea that the FED can always step in and buy up assets whenever the market needs them to, and having the FED reduce its minimum amount of purchases does not stop the fact that the FED could always purchase more if necessary. However, if the Fed stated that they are ending the program altogether that would be a completely different type of signal. If the market knew that the Fed was not there to buy treasuries on the back end I think it would do quite a bit to reduce purchases on the front end. All of this "tapering" is also data dependent. Do we really think there are going to be no economic hiccups in the next 6 months? With central banks around the world all winding down their asset purchases, who is going to purchase US debt? They just signed a trillion dollar plus infrastructure plan and they are about to pass a $1.7 trillion BBB plan. Who is going to buy all of this debt if not the fed, especially if investors suddenly think they have to actually hold the treasuries and the FED is not there to buy it off them on the back end. All these treasuries have negative real returns. What honest to God investor would want that? It's better than cash for the short term as long as you know you can offload it, but if there's no one to offload it to you're stuck with a negative yield for the term.
Spectacularly wrong.  Me and the fed. Lol

Morgan Stanley research predicts no rate hikes in 2022. 
https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/morgan-stanley-heres-why-we-see-no-rate-hikes-2022-and-what-means-markets

Fed has two jobs: keep inflation in check (around 2%) + keep unemployment low  As the economy is going/recovering, it well could be that the Fed stops buying mid 2022; However, I think this won't happen just yet, because of the unemployment issue. The Fed still cannot afford to tighten the market - stop the QE and increase the rate - when there is uncertainty around what will happen in the labour market.  https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/03/business/economy/fed-taper-bond-buying.html
https://www.reuters.com/business/federal-reserves-taper-how-does-it-work-2021-11-03/

The market is smarter than me, and futures have priced in one rate hike before July 2022 (2.5 by 31DEC2022), and I think any QE cessation announcement will precede rate hike. (Following citation is offered for the futures charts... not for the commentary)
https://www.zerohedge.com/economics/even-wsj-admits-market-now-betting-fed-policy-error

I don't think Powell is inclined to rock the boat before his term ends in February 2022. That said, half of the FOMC sees rate increases in 2022, the whole FOMC sees rate increases in 2023, and I expect that QE will be ended before rates increase.

Using some notes from this posting  [https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1352399](https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1352399)  “The Committee seeks to achieve maximum employment and inflation at the rate of 2 percent over the longer run. With inflation having run persistently below this longer-run goal, the Committee will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer‑term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent. “
——
With Inflation around 6.2 as of today (highest for 30 years), there should be some expectation that the FOMC are not going to try to move quickly as many of the statements regarding inflation right now is that its “transitory” and chair member are echoing expectations of jobs being fulfilled and supply chain issues to ease early 2022. If news about the federal funds rate potentially rising then most likely the announcement on concluding the bond buying will be around the corner.

consensus views around accelerating taper are too hawkish, Fed expects a pickup in inflation and likely wouldn't even start to accelerate pace until 2Q at earliest, not impossible that it ends before May 4 but low probability event

Maybe this question will help me make up for how terribly I did on the last tapering question. So far the little bit of tapering they have done has not had much impact, but I think it's important to keep in mind that the national government has been dealing with the debt ceiling and has been issuing less debt than normal. Once the debt ceiling issue is resolved and once the infrastructure plan gets passed there's going to be trillions of dollars worth of treasuries issued which the Federal Reserve will likely need to purchase.  So far Powell has made it clear that any additional tapering will be totally dependent on the data. And I'm confident if the Fed has to choose between inflation and the stock market it will always choose to stimulate the stock market. I expect that before they ever taper off quantitative easing completely they will reverse course and increase the purchases. And certainly we will never get so far as actually raising the federal funds rate. If they were actually serious about combating the inflation they'd be raising the federal funds rate to 6 or 8% right now but that would be instant depression. CPI is at 6.2% annual right now, and is set to rise because producer price increases are over 8% and companies have been hesitant to pass those costs on to consumers but it will happen eventually. What real investor in their right mind would pay 1.55% for a 10-year treasury when inflation is over 6%? The only reason treasury rates are so low is because of Federal Reserve is buying them on the back end and the federal government cannot afford to pay a market rate of interest, so the Federal Reserve can't ever stop buying.
I expect the announcement after the May 3-4 meeting.
